lines.text: The two of you together. That's fine. But what if one of you is the monster?
Monster? We're British, you know.
Oh, yes, England. Queen Victoria, crumpets, Shakespeare.
I admire Poland, madam. I believe there is a bond between our two countries.
My husband, the Count Petrovski, says that in the fifteenth century your King Henry betrayed us to the Russians. Hmm?
I hope that you and your husband, madam, will accept my profoundest apologies.
Miss Jones, I shall need your assistance.

[eyeing Wells' dinner companion]
Yes, well at your age I'm not surprised.
With an autopsy!
Oh, well that's different.
Now, anything, anything that moves near that door, kill it!
But what if the monk is innocent?
Ahhh, we got *lots* of innocent monks!
You're in bad humour because you've lost your box of bones, hmm?

That box of bones, madame, could have solved many of the riddles of science. If the theory of evolution is confirmed, if the science of biology is revolutionized, if the very origin of man is determined ...
I have heard of evolution. It's... it's immoral!
It's a fact. And there's no morality in a fact.
Miss Jones, allow me to introduce Professor Alexander Saxton. He dabbles in fossils and bones.
Glad to meet you, Professor.
How do you do?
Miss Jones has been assisting me. Bacteriology, excellent technician.

[laughs]
For a woman, he means.
[after Wells buys his way onto a full train]
It's called "squeeze" in China. The Americans call it knowhow.
And in Britain, we call it bribery and corruption.
What are you going to astound the scientific world with this time?
You'll read about it in the Society's annual report. A remarkable fossil.
Fossil? But you've got something live in there, I heard it.
You're mistaken!
You won't need to feed it then.
The occupant hasn't eaten in two million years.
That's one way to economize on food bills.
I'm an engineer. A scientist. And this is ordinary chalk. How do you explain it not writing on that crate?
Hypnosis! Yoga! These mystics can be terribly convincing. They can even hypnotize themselves.
[Mirov has opened the crate and found the body of the missing baggage man inside it]
Are you telling me that an ape that lived two million years ago got out of that crate, killed the baggage man and put him in there, then locked everything up neat and tidy, and got away?
Yes, I am! It's alive, it must be!
Is it true you're a doctor?
Ask me when I've finished my dinner.
[talking about the creature with Saxton]
You mean it sucked other people's brains?
The czar will hear of this. I'll have you sent to Siberia.
I am in Siberia!
Tell me, Mirov, what do you know about all the filth that's going on here?
He knows that a horse has four legs. He knows that a murderer has two arms. But still, the devil must be afraid of one honest Cossack.
[opening narration]

The following report to the Royal Geological Society by the undersigned, Alexander Saxton, is a true and faithful account of events that befell the Society's expedition in Manchuria. As the leader of the expedition, I must accept responsibility for its ending in disaster, but I leave to the judgement of the honorable members of the Society the decision as to where the blame for the catastrophe lies.
Where there is God, there is always a place for the cross. Even on this stone floor, just so. But Satan is evil, and where there is evil, there is no place for the cross.
There's a stink of hell on this train. Even the dog knows it!
You are jesting with her immortal soul!
That's why we keep you, Pujardov. Our immortal souls are your concern.
Forgive me, your Excellency. In my concern for the spiritual welfare of the countess, I forgot myself. I will pray for humility.
Pray hard, Pujardov. Or you'll find yourself praying for a job, too.

[regarding Saxton's crate]
One man dead, another missing. It's time we opened that box!
And what about the baggage man? And that poor thief at the station?
What about them?
They are dead. Was your creature responsible for that?
Probably.
And you don't care?

[reflectively]
A baggage man, and a thief... You're right madame. I don't care... as much as I should.
[about the condition of a dead man's brain]
Smooth as a baby's bottom!
The beast is not dead.
I put four bullets into him.

[smiling]
You think evil can be killed with bullets? Satan lives. The Unholy One is among us.
Peasants! Peasants!
I don't want to panic the passengers.
